examSection: NSW Selective High School Placement Test
updateNotes: Comprehensive update adding 20 question archetypes, distractor patterns, visual diagram types, and additional misconceptions based on deep analysis of official NSW practice tests

curriculumAlignment.note: Questions draw upon concepts students learn at school up to Year 6 - no extra knowledge required
curriculumAlignment.emphasis: Mathematical reasoning and problem-solving over procedural calculation

keyConcepts.name: Mental Calculation Fluency
keyConcepts.description: Rapid and accurate mental arithmetic without calculator

keyConcepts.name: Fraction-Decimal-Percentage Fluency
keyConcepts.description: Understanding and converting between rational number representations

keyConcepts.name: Order of Operations
keyConcepts.description: Applying BODMAS/PEMDAS correctly in multi-step calculations

keyConcepts.name: Measurement and Calculation
keyConcepts.description: Perimeter, area, volume calculations and unit conversions
criticalSkills: Area of rectangles, triangles, composite shapes

keyConcepts.name: Spatial Reasoning
keyConcepts.description: Visualising and reasoning about 2D and 3D shapes

keyConcepts.name: Pattern Recognition
keyConcepts.description: Identifying and extending numerical and visual patterns

keyConcepts.name: Problem Solving Strategies
keyConcepts.description: Applying reasoning to multi-step word problems

commonMisconceptions.misconception: 1/5 is smaller than 1/10 because 5 is smaller than 10
commonMisconceptions.correction: With unit fractions, the larger the denominator, the smaller the fraction. Think: sharing a pizza among 10 people gives smaller pieces than sharing among 5.
commonMisconceptions.source: Driver et al., Children's Errors in Mathematics
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Present fraction comparison questions that expose whole-number thinking

commonMisconceptions.correction: Compare place values: 0.45 = 0.450, which has 4 tenths vs 1 tenth in 0.123
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include decimal comparisons with different digit counts

commonMisconceptions.misconception: 0.47 < 0.2 because hundredths are smaller than tenths
commonMisconceptions.correction: The quantity matters: 47 hundredths is more than 2 tenths (47/100 > 20/100)
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Mix decimal comparisons requiring place value reasoning

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Using additive reasoning: if 2:3 → then 4:5 (adding 2 to each)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Ratios use multiplicative relationships: 2:3 → 4:6 (multiply both by 2)
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include ratio problems that catch additive thinking errors

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Adding same number to numerator and denominator doesn't change the fraction (e.g., 2/3 = 4/5)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Only multiplying/dividing both by same number preserves the fraction's value
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Equivalent fraction questions with additive distractors

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Confusing area and perimeter formulas - using multiplication for perimeter
commonMisconceptions.correction: Perimeter = distance around (add sides); Area = surface space (multiply dimensions)
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Questions requiring both area and perimeter to expose confusion

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Same perimeter = same area (or vice versa)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Rectangles with equal perimeter can have different areas (e.g., 1×9 and 4×6 both have P=20, but A=9 vs A=24)
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include questions comparing shapes with same perimeter but different areas

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Using perimeter or area formula for volume
commonMisconceptions.correction: Volume = length × width × height (3 dimensions); measured in cubic units
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Volume problems with 2D formula results as distractors

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Equiprobability bias: all outcomes equally likely (e.g., two dice sums all equal probability)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Some outcomes have more combinations: sum of 7 has 6 ways, sum of 2 has only 1 way
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include compound probability questions exposing equiprobability bias

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Two coins: HH, TT, HT are equally likely outcomes
commonMisconceptions.correction: HT can occur two ways (HT or TH), so P(one of each) = 2/4 = 1/2, not 1/3
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Coin/dice problems requiring systematic outcome counting

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Working left to right regardless of operation precedence
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include expressions where left-to-right gives wrong answer

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Equal sign means 'the answer is' rather than 'is the same as'
commonMisconceptions.correction: Equal sign shows equivalence: 5 + 2 = 3 + 4 is valid because both equal 7
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include equations where number appears on right side of equals

commonMisconceptions.correction: On number line, further left = smaller. -5 is 5 below zero, -2 is only 2 below
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include negative number comparisons and operations

commonMisconceptions.misconception: A rotated shape is a different shape
commonMisconceptions.correction: Rotation preserves shape identity; a rotated square is still a square
commonMisconceptions.testingStrategy: Include shape recognition with non-standard orientations

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Estimating angles by visual appearance without reference to right angles
commonMisconceptions.correction: Use 90° as benchmark: acute < 90°, obtuse > 90°, reflex > 180°

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does cutting a pizza into 8 pieces give you more pieces but less pizza per piece than cutting into 4?
Is 25% off better than buy-2-get-1-free? How do you know?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Recipe scaling for different group sizes
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A recipe serves 4 people. How do you adjust it for a party of 15?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Packing boxes in a shipping container
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How many shoeboxes can fit in a large shipping container?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Reading a map and estimating distances
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: If 1 cm on the map = 5 km in real life, how far is it between two cities 8 cm apart?
Which cricketer has the better batting average, and what does that really tell us?
How many different views can you see from a 3D LEGO structure?
In Monopoly, which properties are you most likely to land on after rolling two dice?
How many square tiles do you need to cover a rectangular bathroom floor?
If you miss the 9:15 train, which later train gets you there fastest?

phase2.name: Connections
phase2.focus: Linking concepts and applying to contexts

phase3.name: Reasoning
phase3.focus: Complex problem solving and mathematical reasoning

phase4.name: Integration
phase4.focus: Synthesising across strands under time pressure
phase4.questionTypes: Exam-style questions with distractors targeting misconceptions

cognitiveLoadNotes: Working memory limited to ~4 items for children - chunk problems into steps
Multi-step word problems require storing intermediate results while processing
Unfamiliar contexts increase cognitive load - use familiar Australian scenarios
Visual representations (diagrams, number lines) offload working memory
engagementStrategies: Use cognitive offloading: scratch paper, jotting intermediate answers
Teach chunking: break complex problems into manageable sub-problems
Connect to real-world contexts meaningful to Year 6 students
Use prediction before calculation to engage reasoning
Provide worked examples before independent practice
motivationFactors: Connect maths to student interests (sports, games, technology)
Emphasise that reasoning ability can be developed with practice
Celebrate strategic thinking, not just correct answers
Use slightly challenging problems (zone of proximal development)
testTakingStrategies: Read the question twice before calculating
Use process of elimination on multiple choice
Flag difficult questions and return later
Check units match the question requirements
Don't leave any questions blank (no negative marking)

distractorDesign: Include common misconception answers as distractors
Use computational error results (off-by-one, wrong operation)
Include partial solution answers for multi-step problems
Use plausible-looking numbers from misread data
difficultyProgression: Start with direct application of single concept
Progress to multi-step problems requiring concept integration
Advance to non-routine problems requiring strategy selection
Challenge with problems requiring reasoning beyond standard procedures
contextVariation: Word problems with realistic Australian contexts

assessmentCriteria.reasonableness: Checking answers make sense in context

overview.description: Almost ALL Mathematical Reasoning questions are word problems presented in unfamiliar contexts that require students to translate language into mathematical operations and combine multiple concepts to reach a solution.
overview.keyInsight: The test assesses mathematical REASONING, not procedural calculation. Questions are deliberately framed in novel situations to test whether students truly understand mathematics or have just memorised procedures.
coreSkillsTested: Translating word problems into mathematical equations/operations
Applying foundational math knowledge quickly and accurately
Combining multiple concepts within a single problem
Managing cognitive load across multi-step solutions

questionCategories.name: Multi-Step Word Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems requiring 2-4 sequential operations with intermediate results
framingPatterns: Price/cost problems with multiple items and constraints
Time and journey problems with multiple legs
Age problems with relationships between people
Work problems involving rates and sharing

exampleStructure.stimulus: A burger and a drink cost $6.00. Chips and a drink cost $3.75. A burger, chips and a drink cost $8.50.
exampleStructure.question: What is the cost of a burger and chips?
steps: Find drink cost: Compare equations to isolate variables
exampleStructure.cognitiveLoad: High - must track multiple unknowns and relationships

questionCategories.name: Data Interpretation Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems requiring reading graphs, tables, or charts then performing calculations
framingPatterns: Read values from graph → perform calculation

exampleStructure.stimulus: A bar graph shows class sizes for Classes 1-5. Total students in school = 160.
exampleStructure.question: How many students are in Class 6?
steps: Determine the graph scale from a known value
Read and sum all visible class sizes
Subtract from total to find Class 6
exampleStructure.cognitiveLoad: Medium-High - requires scale inference and multiple reads

questionCategories.name: Spatial/Geometric Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems involving 2D/3D shapes, properties, and visualisation
framingPatterns: Calculate faces + edges + vertices of 3D shapes
Interpret nets and identify matching 3D shapes
Count cubes in 3D structures (visible and hidden)

exampleStructure.stimulus: A pyramid has a pentagonal base.
exampleStructure.question: What is the sum of the number of faces, edges, and vertices?

questionCategories.name: Pattern and Sequence Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems requiring identification and application of number patterns
framingPatterns: Find missing term in a sequence
Determine the rule and apply it

exampleStructure.question: What is the value of ▲?
steps: Test relationships: ×3-1? No. ×n+? Test multiple hypotheses
Identify rule: multiply by n, then add n (or similar)
Apply rule to find missing term

questionCategories.name: Ratio and Proportion Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems involving multiplicative relationships and scaling

exampleStructure.stimulus: I have an equal number of $1 and $2 coins. Total value is $54. $1 coins weigh 9g, $2 coins weigh 7g.
exampleStructure.question: What is the total weight of all coins?

questionCategories.name: Probability and Statistics Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems involving chance, averages, and data analysis
framingPatterns: Find missing value to achieve target mean

exampleStructure.stimulus: Mean of 12 numbers is 12. A new number is added and the mean becomes 17.
exampleStructure.question: What is the new number?

questionCategories.name: Time and Timetable Problems
questionCategories.description: Problems involving time zones, durations, schedules

exampleStructure.stimulus: Jessica leaves Sydney at 7am on a 3-hour flight to Shanghai (+2hrs timezone), then after 4-hour stopover flies 14 hours to London (-8hrs from Shanghai).
exampleStructure.question: What time is it in Sydney when she arrives in London?
steps: Track each leg: departure + flight + stopover + flight
Convert between timezones at each point
exampleStructure.cognitiveLoad: Very High - multiple time conversions and tracking

multiConceptIntegration.principle: Questions rarely test single concepts in isolation. Instead, they deliberately combine 2-4 concepts requiring students to recognise which mathematical tools apply.

commonCombinations.example: A shop offers 20% off. If the sale price is $48, what was the original price?
Find the area of an L-shaped figure given some dimensions and the perimeter
Three friends share costs in ratio 2:3:5. If the total is $120, how much does each pay?
The average of 5 numbers is 8. Four numbers are 6, 7, 9, 10. What is the fifth?
How many unit cubes are in a 3×4×5 rectangular prism with a 1×2×3 hole?
A bag has twice as many red as blue marbles. P(green) = 0.3. What is P(red)?

workBackwards.description: Start from the answer and reverse operations - useful when final result is given
workBackwards.whenToUse: Problems giving the end state and asking for starting value
workBackwards.example: After a 25% discount, price is $60. Original price?

makeOrganisedList.whenToUse: Problems with multiple combinations or outcomes
makeOrganisedList.example: How many ways to make 50c with 10c and 20c coins?

drawDiagram.description: Create visual representation to clarify relationships
drawDiagram.whenToUse: Spatial problems, journey problems, part-whole relationships
drawDiagram.example: Venn diagram for overlapping areas problem

guessCheckRefine.description: Make educated guess, test, adjust based on result
guessCheckRefine.whenToUse: When working forwards is complex; use middle MC option first
guessCheckRefine.example: For MC questions, test option C first to narrow down

simplifyProblem.example: Solve for one unknown first, then use it to find others

characteristics: Often include challenging spatial or algebraic reasoning

commonTraps: Keywords can be misleading - 'more than' can indicate subtraction in comparison problems
Order matters: 'A is 5 more than B' means A = B + 5, not B = A + 5
Multiple unknowns require tracking relationships, not just operations
translationProcess: 2. Identify WHAT is being asked (the unknown)
3. Identify GIVEN information (known values and relationships)
7. Check answer makes sense in context

questionArchetypes.description: Specific recurring question patterns from official NSW Selective practice tests

archetypes.name: Playlist/Sequence Duration
archetypes.pattern: Multiple items with progressively changing values
archetypes.example: Ngali has a music playlist. The first song is 4 minutes long. There are 3 more songs, and each song is 30 seconds shorter than the song before it. What is the total length?
archetypes.solutionApproach: List all values (4:00, 3:30, 3:00, 2:30), sum them
commonErrors: Forgetting to count the first item

archetypes.name: Weight/Mass Equivalence
archetypes.pattern: Two types of objects with known ratio and one known weight
archetypes.example: Kevin has some identical cubes and some identical spheres. The weight of 8 cubes is the same as the weight of 5 spheres. One sphere weighs 560g. How much does one cube weigh?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Find total weight of 5 spheres → divide by 8 cubes

archetypes.name: 3D Shape Properties
archetypes.pattern: Calculate sum of faces, edges, vertices for non-standard shape
archetypes.example: What is the sum of the number of faces, edges and vertices of a pyramid with a pentagonal base?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Faces: 1 base + n sides = 6; Edges: n base + n lateral = 10; Vertices: n base + 1 apex = 6; Sum = 22

archetypes.name: Multi-Leg Journey with Time Zones
archetypes.pattern: Travel across multiple locations with different time zones and stopovers
archetypes.example: Jessica leaves Sydney at 7am on a 3-hour flight to Shanghai (+2hrs timezone), then after 4-hour stopover flies 14 hours to London (-8hrs from Shanghai). What time is it in Sydney when she arrives?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Track elapsed time, convert only when asked for specific timezone answer
commonErrors: Adding time zones instead of tracking elapsed time

archetypes.name: Simultaneous Price Equations
archetypes.pattern: Multiple menu items with combined prices, find individual or new combination
archetypes.example: A burger and a drink cost $6.00. Chips and a drink cost $3.75. A burger, chips and a drink cost $8.50. What is the cost of a burger and chips?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Find drink by comparing equations; find individual items; combine as requested

archetypes.name: Coin/Object Pairing
archetypes.pattern: Equal numbers of two different valued items with known total
archetypes.example: I have an equal number of $1 and $2 coins. Total value is $54. $1 coins weigh 9g, $2 coins weigh 7g. What is the total weight?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Each pair = $3; Number of pairs = $54÷$3 = 18; Weight = 18×9g + 18×7g
commonErrors: Dividing total by individual coin value

archetypes.name: Venn Diagram Area Problem
archetypes.pattern: Overlapping regions with given totals for each category
archetypes.example: Island total area = 164 km². Area with hills = 132 km². Area with bush = 80 km². How much has neither?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Use inclusion-exclusion: A∪B = A + B - A∩B; Find overlap; Subtract from total

archetypes.name: Missing Value for Target Mean
archetypes.pattern: Given mean and most values, find the missing one
archetypes.example: The mean of 12 numbers is 12. A new number is added and the mean becomes 17. What is the new number?

archetypes.name: Pattern Sequence with Complex Rule
archetypes.pattern: Number sequence with non-obvious multi-operation rule
archetypes.example: What is the missing number: 2, 5, 14, ▲, 122, 365?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Test multiple rules (×n, +n, combination); Verify pattern fits all terms
commonErrors: Not testing rule on all given terms

archetypes.name: Three-Way Relationship Vote/Score Problem
archetypes.pattern: Three quantities with relative differences and total/average given
archetypes.example: Alfred received 13 more votes than Glenda. Glenda received 14 fewer than Shane. Average votes = 33,000. How many did Alfred get?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Express all in terms of one variable; Use mean = total/3; Solve and back-substitute

archetypes.name: Percentage Equivalence/Comparison
archetypes.pattern: X% of A equals Y% of B, find relationship
archetypes.example: 10% of Joey's money = 25% of Peter's money. Joey's money is what % of Peter's?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Set up equation: 0.10J = 0.25P; Solve for J/P; Convert to percentage

archetypes.name: Multi-Ratio Recipe Problem
archetypes.pattern: Multiple ratios connecting three or more ingredients
archetypes.example: Recipe needs 2× as much milk as sugar and 3× as much sugar as butter. How much sugar in 312kg of frosting?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Express all in terms of one ingredient (butter:sugar:milk = 1:3:6); Find parts; Calculate

archetypes.name: Reverse Percentage (Find Original)
archetypes.pattern: Final value after percentage change, find original
archetypes.example: After 25% discount, price is $60. What was the original price?
archetypes.solutionApproach: $60 represents 75% → Original = $60 ÷ 0.75 = $80

archetypes.name: Cube Structure with Paint/Hidden Cubes
archetypes.pattern: 3D structure painted, count cubes with specific face coverage
archetypes.example: A rectangular prism made of small cubes is painted. How many small cubes have grey paint on exactly 2 faces?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Identify positions: corners=3 faces, edges=2 faces, faces=1 face, interior=0 faces

archetypes.name: Scale/Proportion Weight Problem
archetypes.pattern: Similar objects with known dimensions, find weight of larger
archetypes.example: Two solid rectangular prisms from same material. Smaller weighs 600g with dimensions A. Larger has dimensions B. What does larger weigh?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Find linear scale factor; Cube it for volume ratio; Multiply weight
commonErrors: Using linear scale factor for weight

archetypes.name: Timetable Navigation
archetypes.pattern: Use schedule/table to calculate total time or optimal route
archetypes.example: Christine catches the second train, shops for 1hr, and returns on next available train. How long is she away?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Extract relevant times from table; Add travel + activity + return travel

archetypes.name: Age Relationship Problem
archetypes.pattern: Ages at different points in time with relationships
archetypes.example: Three years ago, Sunil and Helen's total age was 27. In five years, what will be their total age?
archetypes.solutionApproach: 8 years pass (from -3 to +5); Two people age 8 years each = 16 years total added; 27 + 16 = 43

archetypes.name: Systematic Counting/Combinations
archetypes.pattern: How many ways to arrange/select with constraints
archetypes.example: Using digits 3,4,5,6, how many 4-digit numbers greater than 6000 can be made?
archetypes.solutionApproach: First digit must be 6; Remaining 3 positions have 3! arrangements = 6
commonErrors: Allowing repeated digits when not permitted

archetypes.name: Shaded Region Area
archetypes.pattern: Composite shape with region removed or highlighted
archetypes.example: A square has a quarter-circle removed. Find the shaded area.
archetypes.solutionApproach: Calculate whole shape area; Subtract removed shape area
commonErrors: Forgetting to use quarter/half of circle

archetypes.name: Speed-Distance-Time Multi-Part
archetypes.pattern: Journey with different speeds/distances, find average or total
archetypes.example: First 120km takes 2hrs; next 180km takes 4hrs. What is average speed for entire journey?
archetypes.solutionApproach: Total distance = 300km; Total time = 6hrs; Average speed = 50km/h

distractorPatterns.description: How incorrect answers are designed to catch common errors

patterns.description: Answer represents completing only part of the multi-step problem
patterns.example: If question needs A×B÷C, one distractor is just A×B

patterns.description: Result of using addition instead of subtraction (or vice versa), multiplication instead of division
patterns.example: If answer is 100-35=65, distractor might be 100+35=135

patterns.description: Answer that results from applying a known misconception
patterns.example: For reverse percentage, adding the percentage instead of dividing

patterns.description: Off by factor of 10, 100, or 1000 due to unit conversion or decimal error
patterns.example: Answer in kg when question asks for grams

patterns.description: Using the inverse of the correct ratio relationship
Answer that is one more or one less than correct
patterns.example: Counting problem where student counts start or end position wrong

patterns.description: Numbers that look reasonable and fall between extremes
patterns.example: If correct answer is 288, distractors might be 180, 240, 300, 360

patterns.description: Result of applying wrong formula (area vs perimeter, mean vs median)
patterns.example: Using perimeter formula when area is asked

distractorPatterns.testStrategy: Work backwards from answer options to test which one satisfies all conditions; if answer options are ordered, test middle option first to eliminate half

visualDiagramQuestions.description: Questions that include diagrams, images, or visual information

types.note: Often marked 'NOT DRAWN TO SCALE' - use given numbers, not appearance
